channel.title: whonixsetup (CLI)
channel.description:
https://github.com/Whonix/whonixsetup as standalone:
│ python3 -c 'from anon_connection_wizard import tor_status; tor_status.set_enabled()' │ │ returned exit code 1, which means failed to enable Tor. │ │ │ │ Error messages are as follows: │ │ Traceback (most recent call last): │ │ File "<string>", line 1, in <module> │ │ ImportError: No module named 'anon_connection_wizard' │ │ │ │ If some dependencies are missing (for example, cannot import name 'tor_status'): │ │ sudo apt-get install anon-connection-wizard
It doesn't have a dependency on anon-connection-wizard. And now with tor-control-panel vs anon-connection-wizard, something to keep in mind.
//cc @iry @troubadour @Algernon

item.title: whonixsetup (CLI)
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
whonixsetup currently does not work at all, neither disabling nor enabling Tor does anything.

Read full topic

item.title: whonixsetup (CLI)
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Let’s put merging whonixsetup into whonix-setup-wizard on hold so we have separated CLI and GUI packages. //cc @iry

These are the 3 occurrences of using tor_status in whonixsetup which causes a dependency on tor-control-panel.

github.com

Whonix/whonixsetup/blob/master/usr/lib/whonixsetup_/ft_m_1#L83

    

  1. if [ ! "$exit_code" = "0" ]; then
    2. 

  2. ## Back to main menu.
    3. 

  3. exit 0
    4. 

  4. fi
    5. 

  5. 

    6. 

  6. ## set_enabled() function will:
    7. 

  7. ## 1. create 40_tor_control_panel.conf if it was missing
    8. 

  8. ## 2. set final value of DisableNetwork in the file to 0
    9. 

  9. ## 3. restart Tor using systemd
    10. 

  10. 

    11. 

  11. error_msg="$(python3 -c 'from tor_control_panel import tor_status; tor_status.set_enabled()' 2>&1)" || { exit_code="$?" ; true; };
    12. 

  12. 

    13. 

  13. if [ "$exit_code" != "0" ]; then
    14. 

  14.  TITLE="whonixsetup - Error!"
    15. 

  15.  MSG="
    16. 

  16. python3 -c 'from tor_control_panel import tor_status; tor_status.set_enabled()'
    17. 

  17. returned exit code $exit_code, which means failed to enable Tor.
    18. 

  18. 

    19. 

  19. Error messages are as follows:
    20. 

  20. $error_msg
    21. 

  21. 

    22.
github.com

Whonix/whonixsetup/blob/master/usr/lib/whonixsetup_/ft_m_1#L88

    

  1. ## set_enabled() function will:
    2. 

  2. ## 1. create 40_tor_control_panel.conf if it was missing
    3. 

  3. ## 2. set final value of DisableNetwork in the file to 0
    4. 

  4. ## 3. restart Tor using systemd
    5. 

  5. 

    6. 

  6. error_msg="$(python3 -c 'from tor_control_panel import tor_status; tor_status.set_enabled()' 2>&1)" || { exit_code="$?" ; true; };
    7. 

  7. 

    8. 

  8. if [ "$exit_code" != "0" ]; then
    9. 

  9. TITLE="whonixsetup - Error!"
    10. 

  10. MSG="
    11. 

  11. python3 -c 'from tor_control_panel import tor_status; tor_status.set_enabled()'
    12. 

  12. returned exit code $exit_code, which means failed to enable Tor.
    13. 

  13. 

    14. 

  14. Error messages are as follows:
    15. 

  15. $error_msg
    16. 

  16. 

    17. 

  17. If some dependencies are missing (for example, cannot import name 'tor_status'):
    18. 

  18. sudo apt-get install tor-control-panel
    19. 

  19. 

    20. 

  20. If there is something wrong with your Tor config, you can open /usr/local/etc/torrc.d/50_user.conf in the terminal:
    21. 

  21. sudo nano /usr/local/etc/torrc.d/50_user.conf
    22.
github.com

Whonix/whonixsetup/blob/master/usr/lib/whonixsetup_/ft_m_2#L68

    

  1. if [ ! "$exit_code" = "0" ]; then
    2. 

  2. ## Back to main menu.
    3. 

  3. exit 0
    4. 

  4. fi
    5. 

  5. 

    6. 

  6. ## set_disabled() function will:
    7. 

  7. ## 1. create 40_tor_control_panel.conf if it was missing
    8. 

  8. ## 2. set final value of DisableNetwork in the file to 1
    9. 

  9. ## 3. stop Tor using systemd
    10. 

  10. 

    11. 

  11. python3 -c 'from tor_control_panel import tor_status; tor_status.set_disabled()' >/dev/null 2>&1  || { exit_code="$?" ; true; };
    12. 

  12. 

    13. 

  13. if [ "$exit_code" = "0" ]; then
    14. 

  14. true "INFO: Ok, exit 1, so whonixsetup will end."
    15. 

  15. dialog --title "whonixsetup - Success!" --msgbox 'Tor networking has been disabled.
    16. 

  16. 

    17. 

  17. Note: whonixsetup disables Tor networking by writing "DisableNetwork 1" to /usr/local/etc/torrc.d/40_tor_control_panel.conf
    18. 

  18. ' 640 480
    19. 

  19. ## Signal for whonixsetup to break the while loop.
    20. 

  20. exit 1
    21. 

  21. else
    22.

Could you move the code required to remove the dependency into anon-shared-helper-scripts please? @troubadour

Read full topic

item.title: whonixsetup (CLI)
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
https://github.com/Whonix/whonixsetup as standalone:

│ python3 -c 'from anon_connection_wizard import tor_status; tor_status.set_enabled()'                                                         │
│ returned exit code 1, which means failed to enable Tor.                                                                                      │
│                                                                                                                                              │
│ Error messages are as follows:                                                                                                               │
│ Traceback (most recent call last):                                                                                                           │
│   File "<string>", line 1, in <module>                                                                                                       │
│ ImportError: No module named 'anon_connection_wizard'                                                                                        │
│                                                                                                                                              │
│ If some dependencies are missing (for example, cannot import name 'tor_status'):                                                             │
│     sudo apt-get install anon-connection-wizard

It doesn’t have a dependency on anon-connection-wizard. And now with tor-control-panel vs anon-connection-wizard, something to keep in mind.

//cc @iry @troubadour @Algernon

Read full topic
